Yn ogystal â mi eich anffyrdd a datblygu?
Rwy'n ddweud fy enw yw Yvonne Smith.
Datblygu?
Datblygu. Roeddwn i'n niforio yn 4 o ddegwyddo 1942, felly rwy'n 71.
Yn ogystal â mi ychydig am eich ymddygiad yna,
eich mwy, eich fater, a beth maen nhw'n ei wneud ar gyfer ymgyrch a'ch syblion, yna.
Mae'r maen nhw ddim yn gweithio.

a'n cael canser ar ddwy o bryd.

Testiwn o dd Acellewconstans
Un o'r dylion a dwi'n ffyrddol, sy'n byw yn y strwyth nesaf,
roedd hi'n gweithio yn Barnecalfs.
Roedd hi'n dweud i mi bod Mrs Farmer, sy'n gofyn y gwasanaeth,
a'n byw yn ddwy strwythau ystafell,
yn edrych ar unrhyw clac neu'r asistant.
Roedd hi'n dweud,
Go on, off you go, go and knock on Mrs Farmer's door.
I said, I don't know the lady.
Oh yes, she's lovely, go knock on her door.
So I went and I knocked on her door,
and I said, I understand that you're looking for a new assistant,
and I have done some, I got some experience.
And she said, well, come and see me tomorrow,
and I'll do an interview, and we'll see how we go.
And I went along, and she interviewed me,
and she said, right, when can you start?
And I was actually earning, I think about £7.50 a week from £3,
and I couldn't believe my luck to get a job like that.
And it was such a lot of difference in those days.
So can you, were there lots of people in Barnecalfs that you knew?
Yes, when I went there, it actually employed,
if I explained to you that Polycalfs started up in 1940.
It was started up with, I believe it was Lordenafield,
through the war effort, and originally made uniforms for the troops.
It went, and I know that there were records kept from,
it was either 1939 or 1940, and those records were kept
of people who were actually employed there.
And I mean, I'm talking, I went there 1961,
but those records were still there of people who were employed at that time.
So they had actually, and they were handwritten records,
and they were actually kept.
They then diversified, and they made, let me think now,
they used to do, they still made uniforms,
they made ladies' clothing, they also did bedding.
And I mean, before the factory actually closed,
it was there, it then went into Berberys.
That was the way it went, but that was way after I finished,
because it was still Polycalfs when I went there.
They used to make a lot of men's suits and things like that,
and the factory itself was partitioned off into different sections.
I, let me think, I went, part of my job every day was to check everybody who,
every person on the shop floor had to have a clock card.
A clock card.
And throughout the factory there were clocks,
and in the morning when they came into work they clocked in,
and when they went out in the night or lunchtime, they clocked out.
Now those clock cards and the clocks themselves,
there must have been about ten stations, I would have said, throughout the factory,
and every day I checked those clock cards,
and I checked them for lateness,
and if someone was not there, then the clock cards were collected in.
Even sometimes if there were two reds, which meant that they were late,
they were collected in.
And then to get their clock card the following morning,
they had to come and see either the personnel officer or me,
and they had to tell, they had to give a reasonable explanation as to why they were late,
or why they were absent.
And very often I can remember Mrs Farmer,
who was the personnel officer, telling someone,
well I think it's about time you bought yourself a new alarm clock.
You know, it was really quite funny, the things that came out.
What would happen to them if they kept on?
They would be given a warning,
and if they, within a certain period, I can't really remember off hand,
but if it was within a reasonable amount of time,
and I got a feeling it was a month or six weeks or something like that,
and if they were late so many times, they were given a warning,
and then they were put off, they were made redundant.
If they couldn't give a reasonable explanation then,
because there was a big recruitment drive during that time,
and like I say, you were talking about 1800 girls that the factory employed.
Well, not all women, because most of them were pressers,
they were men, they were pattern cutters, most of them were men,
and there was a packing department, and that mostly consisted of men.
So there were a couple of hundred men, I would have said there, but mostly women.
So 1800 was the number of everybody working there?
Of everyone working there, yes.
So what percentage would you say were women?
Well, I would have said approximately 75%, three-quarters women,
because the office staff were mostly women as well.
The managers were men, as they would be, but most of the office staff,
and I can actually remember someone being taken on as a manager who was a woman,
and she was in the design department and of the bedding section,
but that was very unusual, especially in those days,
because women became supervisors, the foremen were usually men.
It was accepted practice in those days, wasn't it?
Women didn't really climb up the ladder, because they didn't get the chance.
Pretty low class ceiling, wasn't it?
Yes, very low class.
Oh great. Tell me then about the first day you entered the factory.
Can you remember what it was like?
Did you go straight on? I mean, did you go in the first few times you went there,
did you go on the factory floor?
Yes, well now the girl whose job I was taking over was leaving to have a baby,
so she was with me for two weeks, so she actually trained me, taught me all the job,
and then on the following week it was, we are off you go, you're on your own,
but I suppose it's one of those things you accepted and you fell into then, wasn't it?
You learnt as you went along, and a lot of it is experience as well.
And Mrs Farmer was a wonderful boss, she really was wonderful.
A lady who never had any children of her own, but was kind,
and she was known to be a very fair manager then as such,
because if any of the factory managers said anything about the girls,
she would have them up and she'd say,
now you tell me your side of the story before anything was ever done.
And she taught me a lot I think, you know, over the years, it was quite surprising.
But while I was there...
Sorry, did the girls on the floor, they found her fair as well?
Oh very fair, oh yes, yes.
How did you get on with the girls on the floor?
Well, mind, one of the funnies which I always remember was we had two nurses,
one was the sister and one was the nurse.
I was trying to remember, I think they were both, one was nursery's and one was sister's,
they both had the same surname, and the nurse was very little,
but she was a bossy boot, she was.
And throughout the middle of the factory, which was a very big building as such, were the toilets.
Now the girls every day, they weren't allowed to smoke on the factory floor,
but they were allowed to smoke in the toilets, so a lot of them would have a break,
and she would say to me, right, come on, off we go.
Oh yes, what have I got to go to?
You've got to come with these girls now and tell them to go downstairs, they've had enough.
So we'd be upstairs now and it was a whole area that you could walk through, very big,
and you'd see the girls and they'd be scuttling now, and they'd be saying, oh, the nurse is coming.
You can imagine, and there'd be rummlers in their hair, or somebody would be doing their nails,
and they'd all be scuttering then.
And she'd say, you've got to tell them as well, and I used to go, oh, no nurse, not today.
And I'd be behind her and I was a lot taller, and I'd be making eyes at the girls and they'd all be scuttering.
But yes, I got on quite well with them.
It was a different relationship in that quite often I was interviewing some of these girls first thing in the morning
because when Mrs Farmer, she became ill and she left me to do an awful lot of the things,
and I actually took charge of the office for about six months because she was ill
and I was just running the office as such.
So you can't discipline people and be best friends with them as well, can you? It's very difficult.
But I was friendly with some of them, and like I say, I'm still friends with them today,
so it's fine. The two friends that I have that I'm very friendly with now,
I didn't actually know them that well when I worked in Palychof.
And they worked on the floor.
Yes.
So did you find it hard to discipline people?
Very hard because I was only young myself, wasn't I?
But when you have a manager standing behind you that tells you that you've got to do it,
because what they used to do then was they knew that I was a bit inexperienced,
so they'd come along and they'd stand behind me, but it was I who had to do the discipline.
But you accept it as part of the job and you move on then, don't you?
I do.
Describe to me, you've told me about, so you spent quite a bit of time on the factory floor.
Yes, I did, yes.
Describe to me physically now what it was like, what it looked like, what it smelled like,
what the ambience was like.
I wouldn't say that there were any particular smells,
but each area had its own ambience, I suppose you would call it.
I was quite friendly with one of the clerks in the packing department,
so I used to spend some time and say good morning to a friend in the packing department.
That was where the men worked and that was where everything was packed
and went out of the factory.
Then you went further in and there were men who, mostly men, who did pressing.
There was then a small department where there were ladies and they did hand sewing.
And then there were the big, long aisles where the sewing machines were
and each one did, some of them were trousers, some of them were jackets,
some of them, there was a pattern department.
So everything was sectioned out basically.
The bedding department then went to a small factory
because they felt that there was more involved, bigger machines,
because they had big machines, and everything was done on a machine then.
They were machine embroidering on duvets and bed covers and things like that.
So where was that factory then?
That was alongside, but it was completely separate.
There was a manager run just that department then.
So did that mean that the factory got even bigger?
Yes, I think it did.
They took more people on?
Yes. And there was a canteen and a very big canteen.
I remember the canteen manager.
I had a friend who worked as a cook in the canteen department
and I also remember they used to make beautiful cakes, these pineapple cakes,
and I've never ever tasted any pineapple cakes like those.
They were absolutely beautiful.
It's that kind of thing I think that you remember, isn't it?
Talking about the canteen then, did everybody use the same canteen?
Yes. Let me think now.
There was a small part of it where the managers went,
but it was a really big canteen because they didn't stagger the lunch hour.
Everyone had a whole hour for lunch, so you had from 12 to 1 every day.
In the mornings there were approximately 40 buses that used to come into the factory to bring the people in.
At lunchtime there would be some buses because obviously if they were living further away they couldn't get there and back.
But there were a certain amount of buses that went as far as, I believe it was Astor and that kind of thing that they knew was accessible.
Sometimes I would go home and have lunch and then come back on a factory bus.
Those buses were free.
Did they segregate in the canteen? Did everybody sit together except for the managers, you said?
There were tables and quite long tables, but I suppose it's like everything else.
If I sat, I sat with the girls from the offices because you sat with your friends and that was the way it worked, wasn't it?
You mixed, but only to a certain extent.
We used to play cards a lot in those days and play for money on a lunch time.
I can vividly remember that and there would be quite big arguments too if you weren't careful.
So what was the price of the food like? Was it reasonable?
It was very reasonable.
Was it subsidised, do you think?
No, I don't think it was subsidised. I never understood it to be subsidised.
Did you still eat there most days, would you say?
Occasionally rather than most days.
Occasionally.
But then when I went there, like I say, it was about 1961, that canteen was used for a lot of things.
They used to have dances and things like that and the dances were held in the canteen.
They used to do, I remember there was workers playtime and they came there and they used to have entertainment and things even on a lunchtime for the workers.
Who arranged that then?
I believe that it was the canteen manager who did all that. He arranged that.
I can't ever remember anyone else saying that they had any hand in that.
So it wasn't arranged by the factories then, was it? Was it encouraged by the factories?
Encouraged by the factories.
But not arranged by them?
Well, Mr Lawrence was a manager within the factory so quite probably when I think about it, possibly the food may have been subsidised to a certain extent as well.
Maybe not run at a profit even.
Because that I suppose was one of the things that you would look at if it was today.
Today they don't do anything unless there's profit involved do they?
But it certainly wasn't done for profit I don't think in those days.
I can't remember anyone ever saying anything about the canteen making money then as such.
Because all of the staff and everything else that were in the canteen were employed by the factory.
So, yes.
What about parties and Christmas do's?
Oh, parties yes, Christmas do's yes.
Now, the day the factory finished, the girls were always, they always finished on a lunch, well the factory finished on a lunch time.
And I used to be quite gutted actually because they all used to go for lunch.
But they would never pay anyone their pay for them to go to lunch.
They had to come back by, I think it was either four o'clock or five o'clock.
And they were handed, I mean in those days you didn't get money paid into the bank, you had a pay packet didn't you?
And everyone was given their pay packets when they came back in to fetch their pay.
If they didn't come back, they didn't have their pay.
It was kept then until after the holidays.
But, and you can imagine a lot of those girls were really, really the worst for wear.
And you can imagine that I can still see a lot of women and a few men.
And those poor men running for their lives down the factory because the women were saying,
I want to come back here and I want to give you a Christmas kiss.
You can just imagine that can't you?
But for myself, I used to have to then, when everyone had clocked out,
I would have to go and collect all the clock cards throughout the factory and sort them,
put them in number order and then book in whether they were late,
if they'd been sick or whatever for that week.
And I was never, I was always the last one in the factory because it was something that I had to do before I was allowed to finish.
On Christmas Eve.
On Christmas Eve.
So they did the wages then, on Christmas Eve did they?
Usually, yes.
And were you involved in doing the wages?
No, I wasn't.
But you were involved in the hours and stuff like that?
Yes, yes, yes.
And all the clock cards then that I had assembled and they were assembled, I think in numerical order,
but I would put them into bands and they went to, I think there were about eight, six or eight girls
in the wages department who worked out all the wages.
And the four men then, or the supervisors as such, would go and fetch their department's wages and pay them out.
So there was a handful of them and you couldn't enjoy them.
Where would they go then?
They'd go to the pubs.
The pubs.
The pubs and they'd all go out for lunch.
Yes.
Yes.
In the day.
Yes, it was either Christmas Eve or the day before maybe.
I can't, I think it must have been about the Christmas Eve because they didn't in those days give you that much time off on a Christmas time, did they?
It would be like Christmas Eve, Boxing Day perhaps, Christmas Day, Boxing Day, anywhere back the following day.
What about, did they have a Christmas do anywhere then? Did you have a Christmas do?
Yes, we used to, they used to have a lot more in the factory than the girls in the offices ever did.
But we did have Christmas dos and this photograph that I've got here is actually a Christmas do that was organised and was within the canteen.
But we also, I believe it was through the union because I know they were really involved in setting up a social club.
And this social club then was set up in, they bought an old vicarage and I was actually involved in doing a lot of the typing and things when the property was bought.
And I can remember being quite involved in that and I was allowed to go and do the typing for that because Mrs Farmer said that I was allowed.
Yes.
You know.
Well we'll talk about that later on.
Yes, right.
Because I know you've got more to say about that as well.
Yes.
I'll say, I'll say.
Now, what about the noise on the factory floor?
Do you remember that?
Noise, yes.
Was it noisy?
Yes, quite noisy.
Yes.
Noisy in that, but not loud noisy, but possibly more when the machines were going and the people were chattering.
They were allowed to talk.
And there was also, there was a tannoy system and there was always music being played on the tannoy system.
Yes, and nobody was ever stopped from talking because.
Did people used to sing as well?
Oh yes.
Did you join in the singing?
Oh no.
Oh definitely not.
Why is that?
Because you were off your stuff or because.
Oh no, because I can't sing.
Yes, quite, yes, they did used to sing, but I can't ever remember anyone having a wonderful voice anyway, but you would have a little chuckle as you passed them and they were singing.
But it was quite noisy and I don't think that because of the tannoy system and things going as well, I don't think that they talked more than they sang.
I think that was the way it went.
So it used to do these clocks.
What else did your working day entail of?
I know you used to do the pick up the clocks and stuff like that.
Yes, yes, well I would type letters.
I would.
Let me see.
I checked references, I interviewed late comers, I kept records for, there was a record card kept for each and every person who was employed.
So what was on the record card then?
There was an entry as to when they were employed, what they were doing, where they worked, if they were lit, if they'd been reprimanded, there were all sorts of things and it was like an envelope then.
And if there was anything that needed to be kept, it was tucked into the envelope.
They checked references because very often girls would say, oh they were experienced and of course if they were experienced they got a better wage.
And then you'd check their references and if they weren't right, then their pay was knocked down.
So that was quite important.
Did you have to dismiss anybody yourself ever?
Yes, yes, a few times.
How did you feel about that?
Well, not good.
Sometimes I felt that they were rather silly and I didn't feel responsible because it was their life that they were being silly about.
I vividly remember one particular girl who was employed in the office and she was actually stealing from other girls.
And you don't feel sorry for someone like that, you just feel that it's rather sad that they've come from a tidy home and things and they've still got to steal from friends.
That's just one of the facts of life, isn't it?
So were you involved in writing references for people as well when they went to their employment?
Yes, yes.
More, I suppose, a pro-former type of thing and Mrs Farmer then would dictate letters to me and then as I got more experienced I would just do it myself type of thing because I knew what to do.
Because like I say it was more of a pro-former, they were employed and they were good workers and whatever.
You just go down that road then, don't you?
Was there anything that you did that you were really sorry you had to do over the years?
I wouldn't say sorry but quite frightened about.
I was asked or I was told by Mrs Farmer, we did sick visiting.
So we would go out sick visiting.
I'd get the chauffeur to take me so I'd be off in the best car.
So who were you visiting on it?
The employees.
Who were sick?
There was one, once, twice, two particular people that I went to visit and one of them was in the mental hospital in Bridgend.
I was taking flowers and fruit for these people and they'd been off quite a while.
But I can always remember going to the mental hospital.
Never ever been anywhere like that before because I was after all only 19, 20 years of age.
And being locked in a, well not so much locked in a room, but between each set of doors you went through,
you were locked in and seeing all these people all down the corridor.
And I was on my own and the blinking chauffeur said, no you're on your own, I'm not coming in there with you.
And I said gee thanks, you know.
But I just, I didn't feel, well yes I was quite frightened I suppose at the time.
But I'm very glad to come out of there and felt so sad for the person that was there.
And I don't think, I went a second time, I think it may have been to see the same lady,
but I don't think she ever came back to work.
Sad, we had very big floods in parts of the Rhondda when I was working.
And we got heavily involved in helping a lot of our people because they were,
like we've had now recently, they were flooded out.
And we had, I think I remember helping to make up parcels of food and everything else,
which was brought into the factory with the canteen.
And all these parcels of food were made up and taking them out to the people who had been flooded out,
that was hard, you know, because you feel you want to help people more
and you can't do more for one than you can for another then.
That I found quite hard.
Did that idea come from the top or from the management?
You know, this idea of, it sounds like quite a philanthropic thing.
Yes, I would have said it was quite probably from Mrs Farmer herself because she went to chapel.
She was quite a caring woman.
And yes, I suppose most of the managers and things and a lot of the girls on the factory floor,
and I do believe that they collected money and things for these people as well,
which was divided up and handed out.
Maybe it wasn't a lot, but it helped pay their wages because a lot of them couldn't come to work.
So it came from the workers and managers rather than from the bosses?
Yes, quite possibly, but then it was, as far as I was aware, it was the managing director and that was the top.
As far as I was aware, there was no, I don't ever remember there being a fuss about owners coming around.
It was the managing director and he was the boss.
And who did you say that was?
He was a Mr Taylor.
And he was a very nice man.
Did he live locally?
I believe he lived in the Vale somewhere, but I can't remember anything else of that.
So do you think Polycov's was a good company to work for then?
In the early days, yes, I suppose they were.
They looked after the welfare very much of the girls because there was a surgery.
The doctor came a couple of times a week, so if the girls had any problems, the doctor was there, so they didn't have to go to the surgery.
What I particularly remember is when the smallpox outbreak was in the Rhondda, the factory, because there was an awful lot of worry within the valleys at that time,
because of course some of these people who had the smallpox were put into a hospital within the Rhondda.
Do you remember when that was?
Yes, 1961.
They organised for everyone who wanted an immunisation against smallpox to come and have it done within the factory.
I was involved in doing these smallpox injections.
I can't remember, I think I was sticking plasters on everyone and helping.
The sister was doing one lot, the doctor was doing the other lot.
I remember the nurse's name now, her name was Nurse Howells.
I was saying to everybody, stop flapping!
I can also remember some of the girls, I can't have an injection like that in my arm, I have to have it in my leg.
People fainted.
You can imagine all this excitement because everyone had to leave their jobs and then come and coo and get these injections.
Records had to be kept as well because they had to make sure that they didn't give them to some of them twice,
because some of them would have had it twice if they could.
Anything for free!
So that was all done in the factory?
That was done within the factory.
So that was a huge procreate camp?
Yes, it was.
It took a lot of organisation.
We also had a problem with TB at one particular point.
I had a particular friend who worked in the factory and she hadn't been very well.
I went to the doctors and I remember saying to Mrs Farmer about it and she said,
I wonder if we can see if we can get the x-ray to do the TB here?
Which they did.
Everyone got an x-ray, most of the people within the factory.
So that was a big organisational thing as well.
It was found that we had, I think, about two dozen girls with TB.
Some of those girls actually were in hospital for quite a long time.
My friend was in hospital for quite a long time.
It was just at the beginning when they used to give penicillin for TB.
But they used to still keep them in hospital for quite a long time.
It was quite a problem and I remember going and taking fruit and flowers and things for quite a few of these girls.
So they wouldn't have known already about this problem?
No, they wouldn't have.
So were they all okay?
Yes, well, I don't remember anyone dying.
But one friend that I have, that I'm very friendly with in the village,
she is actually one of the girls who was in hospital and I know that Jane was in hospital for six months.
And they were some day longer.
Did polycops keep the jobs open for them?
Yes, they did. Yes, yes, yes. Most of the time, yes.
What would happen with sick pay in those days? Do you remember?
No sick pay. No sick pay.
No sick pay. I got sick pay. I got sick pay, but I couldn't tell you what.
But there wasn't any sick pay for people on the factory floor?
No sick pay for the people on the factory floor.
Why do you think there was a, why did they differentiate, do you think?
I don't know, maybe because it was, it would have been a very expensive outlay.
And maybe the factory didn't run on that kind of off scale, I don't know.
It was accepted practice, wasn't it, in those days?
No, the managers got sick pay and things, I'm positive of that.
But I can't actually remember, as far as I was concerned, being ill.
Because when you're young, most of the time anyway, in touch with, you're not ill as you are when you get older, are you?
But no, I don't remember anyone getting sick pay as such.
What was the position of, you know, did you get sick pay from the government?
I can't remember.
Well, you had National Insurance, didn't you?
Yeah.
Because when you were pregnant, you got 11 weeks maternity pay.
But not from the company?
But not from the company, no.
Right.
No, and as with today, they keep your job open and they pay you maternity pay and things within the way you're working.
But in those days they didn't.
It was what you, the maternity pay you had was from the government and that was it.
Were you aware of the differential in pay between men and women in the factory?
Oh, definitely. Oh, definitely the men were paid.
And there'd be perhaps women working alongside the men and they would be paid less.
Do you know how much less?
No, not off the top of my head. I couldn't know. But I know they were paid less.
Do you know what happened when, were you there when the Equal Pay Act came?
No, no, that was 1975, wasn't it?
Was it 70?
No, no, no, because I finished in 1964.
OK. And what was I going to say? Right, you told them about the union.
Now, there was an union in, they were members of the union.
Yes, a very strong union, yes.
Garment Workers?
Garment Workers Union, yes.
And were you a member of the union?
No.
You didn't have an office union?
No, no, no office union.
How did you feel about that?
Never even thought about it.
It wasn't even suggested, I suppose, in those days. It was just accepted practice.
If you worked in an office, you didn't belong to a union.
I had quite a lot of dealings with the union, obviously, through the girls on the factory floor.
And always there was a...
How did those dealings go?
Always well. They were always reasonable, because I think, especially with Mrs Farmer, she was...
Obviously, they disagreed on some things, but she was a reasonable person.
And her outlook was that she always tried to come down on the side of the girls.
That if there was any way that she could keep them, that she possibly could, she would.
She wasn't a higher of fire.
And I think when you've got as many people involved within a large factory like that,
it takes all sorts, doesn't it?
So there are some people, and you've got different kinds of problems that you have to deal with,
where some people have personal problems that they smell, and then people come and say they're not working with them because they smell in.
And that kind of thing.
And how do you deal with that kind of problem, which can be very difficult?
Because you can't very well say, look, you are using a balsorb.
You're going to have a wash, can you?
It can be very difficult to deal with that kind of problem.
Did anybody come to you with personal problems?
Yes, very often.
So you and Mrs Farmer?
Yes.
And you could help to sort them out, could you?
Well, if you possibly could, you would.
So you'd say there was a good relationship between?
Oh, very good.
Well, I suppose you couldn't solve everyone's problems, but you tried to help as much as you possibly could.
Yes.
Were there any disputes when you were there?
Strikes, yes.
How did you deal with those? Did you have to deal with things like that?
I don't know. I've got to think about that.
So do you remember any disputes?
Yes, I do remember disputes.
I remember parts of the factory being on strike.
Quite possibly, I remember the pressers, which was the men, going on strike because they wanted more money.
They weren't being paid enough and they were paid a lot by the hour.
They were paid.
Whereas there was a time and motion department within the factory,
which employed, I think, about three people who timed everything that everyone did within the factory.
But I do remember the pressers going on strike and the union being involved.
The personnel officer, Mrs Farmer, being employed within that.
But it would be more down to the managers on the factory floor.
I think she would only sit in as an observer rather than perhaps sorting and smoothing things over.
Smoothing things over and helping rather than being involved in any of the disputes as such.
I don't think I ever remember her doing anything.
Maybe I'm wrong, but not that I can remember being involved in anything like that.
Was there any unpleasant feeling about it when these disputes would happen between, say, office and floor or management and floor?
There were sometimes disputes more, I think, as far as perhaps the wages department were concerned in the office.
We would perhaps sort out problems if someone had a dispute as far as their wages were concerned.
They'd come to us and they'd say, well, I haven't had enough pay.
Then we'd sit down with them and work it out and say, well, right, okay, tell us what's going on and show us what you think and what you've got.
We'd sort it out and work it from there and then go to the wages department.
There was a woman in charge of the wages department who would sort it out from there.
But that's the kind of situation that we got involved in.
So not an industrial dispute?
Not an industrial dispute as such, no.
Do you remember any trips when you were at Polychrist?
Yes, I do remember going on a trip to London and a whole train full of people.
They used to commandeer a train and the train would go off to London.
I think I went about twice.
So where would this train start from?
It would start from Triochi, pick people up then all the way down the valleys and when you got to London you went your own way and the train would return at a certain time that evening.
And a whole train full of people.
I remember that.
So who would sort of book the train? Do you remember?
No, not at all. I wasn't involved in anything like that.
I wouldn't remember.
I would imagine, because there was a social department, social events department within, I think it was under Mr Lawrence in the canteen.
I think I remember a department and they used to organise the dances and things like that as well, the trips to London. Yes, I do remember that.
So what did you do in London? You said you all went your own way.
I've actually got, and like I say, when my husband comes back I put my hands on it, I've got a photograph standing in Trafalgar Square with some other girls who weren't working in Polycops.
But I'm sure it was on the trip with Polycops, standing with my hands feeding the birds.
Perhaps going and seeing a show, but I can't remember doing much else.
So it wasn't just Polycops employees that were there?
No, you could invite friends and things as well.
Did those happen quite often?
Once a year, it was only a once a year trip.
Always to London or to other places?
No, I can't remember. Perhaps the other women might remember, but I can't remember going anywhere other than London.
Was that fairly, did you pay for those or did they pay for them?
I must have paid for it.
Or did we get it cheap or did we get it free? I can't remember.
I can't remember.
Anyway, you were telling me about the social club.
The social club, yes.
It was called the Polycops Social Club.
I actually met my husband there.
We used to go along and they used to do, it was quite a big social club.
There was an entertainment room where I had gone with a friend.
We were quite a few women friends, girls.
This young boy was in those days.
He came and asked me, could he take me home because there were lions around that night.
I fell for it.
Here I am 51 years later still married to him.
Like I say, we had part of our reception when we got married.
We all went back to the social club after we were married.
I think that was quite accepted in those days.
All the entertainment and things.
It was all homegrown entertainment because everybody sang.
You made your own entertainment then you didn't employ bands or anything else, did you?
Everyone had a good time. You enjoyed it.
Was that in the chapel that was brought in?
It was a vicarage.
What happened to it?
The vicarage is still there but it's more or less derelict now.
It was way before Polycops finished.
I think they may have sold it even because it was actually owned by the people.
I'm sure it was because in those days the girls used to give to the social club.
They paid out of their wages.
We all did.
When we went to London, the social club paid for that trip because we were paying out of our wages for that.
Originally the premises were bought.
I believe they had a mortgage and whatever.
But it was paid out of the wages of the people within the factory.
What was the proportion of single women and married women who worked?
Were there a lot of married women working?
There were quite a lot of married women, yes.
My sister-in-law worked there for many years.
When you got pregnant, your job wasn't kept open for you.
You weren't paid maternity pay or anything in those days so you had to finish.
But if you wanted to go back to work then and there was a job there, then they would give you a job.
It could quite possibly not be something that you'd done before.
But so long as you were a machinist, you were offered the job.
But there was also a training department within the factory run by a lady called Kate, a single lady.
She trained all of the girls who came in to school, 15-year-olds.
She handled all those girls.
She handled it with a rod of iron.
They had to listen to what they were told.

she said you weren't classed as a machinist until you'd had a needle in your finger.
But yes, it was quite surprising how it was run.

yn y ffordd, ond dyna'r ffordd yma oedd yn y dyddiau hwnnw.
Rydw i'n meddwl, rwy'n gallu'n ddod o'r amser,
roedd hi'n cael ffrindio'r bobl yn y ffordd yma
ac yna rydych chi'n gweithio'r bobl yn y ffordd
ac roedden nhw'n dechrau, a oedd hi'n ymwneud â chi'n ymwneud â ni'n dda?
Oherwydd roedden nhw'n gwybod beth yw'n mynd i ni
ac roedd hi'n mynd i un o'r bobl o'r ffordd yma.
Roedd hi'n manawr.
Rydw i'n meddwl, mae'r hyn o bryd yn oed yn oed yn oed, yw'n hynny?
A oedd hi'n bach o'r arasmyn, oherwydd yw'r hyn o bach o'r ffordd yma?
A oedd oedd yn oed yn oed yn oed yn oed, y penderfyniadau'r bobl?
Rydw i'n meddwl bod'r bobl yn ei fwyaf pan oeddant yn oed yn oed yn oed, ond…
Ond…
Yn oed…
Rydw i'n meddwl, os yw'r hyn yn oed yn oed yn oed yn oed,
yna byddwn yn y debyg yma sy'n dechrau â'r pethau fel hyn.
A gallwn i'n deall â'r pethau i unrhyw un, ond nid i'n deall â mi.
Mae'n, rydw i'n meddwl, y ffordd yma, yw'n oed, yw'n oed?
Felly, oedd yn oed yn oed yn oed yn oed i deall â'r pethau?
I ddod o'r bobl? Cymhwynt, yw'n oed.
Ie, ie, ie.
A yna byddwch yn ymwneud â'r manegor,
a'r sector, a'r bobl yn oed.
Oherwydd, gallai ei ddod.
Ie, os ydym wedi'i gynhyrchu.
Byddwch yn oed yn oed yn cael rhywbeth fel hyn
pan mae'r mhen a'r fywyd yn gweithio gyda'ch chi, nid yw'n…
Yn oed, nid yw'n…
Nid yw'n gwirioneddol iawn.
Ond…
Nid yw'n… Nid fel yw'n heddiw.
